verses.text: Then Agrippa said to Paul, 'You are permitted to speak for yourself.' So Paul stretched out his hand and began his defense:
verses.comment: Paul again makes his defense before prominent leaders, a fulfilment of Jesus’ words that Paul would testify before kings (Acts 9:15).

verses.text: 'King Agrippa, I consider myself fortunate that I am able to make my defense before you today regarding all the accusations the Jews bring against me,
verses.comment: Paul expresses respect and his gratitude, showing both prudence and humility in his approach.

verses.text: especially because you are knowledgeable about all the customs and controversies among the Jews. Therefore, I beg you to listen to me patiently.
verses.comment: Paul appeals to Agrippa’s familiarity with Judaism, laying the groundwork for the gospel’s continuity with the Old Testament faith.

verses.text: All the Jews know my manner of life from my youth, which was spent from the beginning among my own people and in Jerusalem.
verses.comment: Paul roots his story in his public, well-attested life among the Jews, establishing credibility for his testimony.

verses.text: They have known for a long time—if they are willing to testify—that according to the strictest sect of our religion I lived as a Pharisee.
verses.comment: Paul affirms his background as a strict Pharisee, underlining both his orthodoxy and shared roots with his accusers.

verses.text: And now I am standing here on trial for the hope of the promise made by God to our fathers,
verses.comment: Paul shows continuity with Jewish faith—the 'promise' refers to the Messiah and resurrection. Throughout, the apostolic faith is rooted in God’s ancient promises.

verses.text: to which our twelve tribes hope to attain, as they earnestly serve God night and day. For this hope I am accused by the Jews, O king!
verses.comment: Twelve tribes recalls the unity and fullness of God’s people. Paul’s faith is fulfillment, not rejection, of Israel’s hope (see Acts 24:15).

verses.text: Why is it considered incredible to any of you that God raises the dead?
verses.comment: Paul appeals to faith in God’s power, as displayed in the resurrection—a central theme and foundation of Christianity.

verses.text: Indeed, I myself thought that I ought to do much against the name of Jesus of Nazareth.
verses.comment: Paul humbly confesses his former opposition to Christ, an example of honest testimony that marks genuine conversion.

verses.text: And this I did in Jerusalem. Not only did I lock up many of the saints in prison by authority from the chief priests, but when they were put to death, I cast my vote against them.
verses.comment: ‘Saints’—an early reference to holy believers. Paul reveals his past zeal, reminiscent of persecutors turned by divine grace.

verses.text: And I punished them often in all the synagogues and tried to force them to blaspheme. I was so furious against them that I even pursued them to foreign cities.
verses.comment: Paul’s compulsion for persecution highlights both the depth of his conversion and the powerful work of grace.

verses.text: While so engaged, as I was journeying to Damascus with authority and commission from the chief priests,
verses.comment: Paul’s story closely matches previous accounts of his conversion, establishing the historicity of these events.

verses.text: at midday, O king, I saw on the way a light from heaven, brighter than the sun, shining around me and those traveling with me.
verses.comment: The divine light signifies direct heavenly intervention, reminiscent of theophanies in the Old Testament.

verses.text: When we had all fallen to the ground, I heard a voice speaking to me in the Hebrew language, ‘Saul, Saul, why are you persecuting me? It is hard for you to kick against the goads.’
verses.comment: 'Persecuting me'—Jesus personally identifies with His followers, underscoring the mystical unity of Christ and His Church (see Acts 9:4; 1 Cor. 12:27).

verses.text: And I said, ‘Who are you, Lord?’ And the Lord said, ‘I am Jesus, whom you are persecuting.
verses.comment: Jesus reveals Himself as the risen Lord. This highlights the continuity between the living Jesus and His people; to persecute the Church is to persecute Christ Himself.

verses.text: But rise and stand on your feet; for I have appeared to you for this purpose: to appoint you as a servant and a witness both of what you have seen and of what I will show you.
verses.comment: Paul is specifically commissioned, by a divine encounter, to apostolic ministry. There is an emphasis on both witness and service.

verses.text: I will rescue you from your own people and from the Gentiles, to whom I am sending you,
verses.comment: The apostolic mission extends to all nations; Paul’s protection is divinely promised, reflecting the pattern of the prophets.

verses.text: to open their eyes, so that they may turn from darkness to light and from the power of Satan to God, that they may receive forgiveness of sins and an inheritance among those who are sanctified by faith in me.'
verses.comment: Paul’s mission is deeply sacramental—moving people from darkness to light, Satan to God. Forgiveness and a spiritual inheritance are benefits for the sanctified, indicating a transformative process rather than simple verbal assent.

verses.text: Therefore, King Agrippa, I was not disobedient to the heavenly vision,
verses.comment: Paul’s obedience to a divine commission sets a paradigm for Christian response to revelation.

verses.text: but declared first to those in Damascus, then in Jerusalem and throughout all the region of Judea, and also to the Gentiles, that they should repent and turn to God, performing deeds appropriate to repentance.
verses.comment: 'Deeds appropriate to repentance' stresses that true conversion includes a lived change—faith produces works. The preaching of repentance echoes prophetic and New Testament teaching alike.

verses.text: For this reason the Jews seized me in the temple and tried to kill me.
verses.comment: Paul’s suffering for the faith mirrors Christ and the prophets, emphasizing that opposition accompanies proclamation of truth.

verses.text: But having obtained help from God, I stand this day testifying both to small and great, saying nothing beyond what the prophets and Moses said would happen:
verses.comment: Christian faith is presented as fulfillment of the Law and the Prophets—Paul is not launching a new religion, but reveals continuity of God’s plan.

verses.text: that the Christ must suffer, and that, by being the first to rise from the dead, he would proclaim light both to our people and to the Gentiles.'
verses.comment: 'Christ must suffer'—a direct fulfillment of Isaiah 53 (see also Luke 24:26). Jesus’ resurrection brings light to all nations, fulfilling salvation history.

verses.text: As he was making his defense in this way, Festus said with a loud voice, 'Paul, you are out of your mind! Your great learning is driving you mad.'
verses.comment: Festus’ response shows the offense of the preaching of resurrection to Gentile hearers. The message challenges worldly wisdom.

verses.text: But Paul replied, 'I am not mad, most excellent Festus, but I speak words of truth and reason.
verses.comment: Christianity is not irrational; Paul affirms the reasonable and historical nature of the faith.

verses.text: For the king knows about these matters, and to him I speak boldly; for I am convinced that none of these things has escaped his notice, for this was not done in a corner.
verses.comment: The gospel is public and verifiable—the events of Jesus’ death and resurrection happened in history, not secrecy.

verses.text: 'King Agrippa, do you believe the prophets? I know that you do.'
verses.comment: Paul appeals to Agrippa’s knowledge of Scripture, drawing a line between prophetic tradition and its fulfillment in Christ.

verses.text: And Agrippa said to Paul, 'In such a short time would you persuade me to become a Christian?'
verses.comment: Agrippa senses the force of Paul’s argument. The term 'Christian' indicates the developing identity of the followers of Christ, united in faith and practice.

verses.text: And Paul said, 'Whether shortly or at length, I would to God that not only you but all who hear me this day might become such as I am, except for these chains.'
verses.comment: Paul’s desire is for everyone to share in communion with Christ, despite his suffering. His testimony models charitable evangelistic zeal.

verses.text: Then the king rose, and the governor and Bernice and those sitting with them,
verses.comment: This marks the formal end of the trial, with all the authorities bearing witness to Paul’s defense.

verses.text: And when they had withdrawn, they said to one another, 'This man is doing nothing worthy of death or imprisonment.'
verses.comment: Paul’s innocence is repeatedly attested, showing that the faith’s advance is not due to rebellion but the work of God.

verses.text: And Agrippa said to Festus, 'This man could have been set free if he had not appealed to Caesar.'
verses.comment: Paul’s appeal to Caesar fulfills his calling to bear witness even in Rome. The hand of Providence is directing every step, in accordance with God’s sovereign purpose.
